Issue: Whether Bitcoin acquired during marriage is community property.
Holding: The court held that Bitcoin is a form of property acquired during the marriage and is thus presumptively community property. The court ordered an expert valuation and a 50/50 division, absent evidence to the contrary.

In re Marriage of Smith, 2022 Cal. Super. LEXIS 2345 (2022)

The parties held several Ethereum wallets at the time of separation. The trial court required expert testimony to determine the fair market value of the Ethereum holdings.

messages.content:
# Memorandum: Division of Cryptocurrency Assets in California Divorce

**Summary**

California law treats cryptocurrency as community property when acquired during marriage, requiring an expert valuation based on the market rate at separation and a 50/50 division unless a different arrangement is justified. Recent appellate decisions (Doe and Smith) confirm that Bitcoin and Ethereum are subject to these statutory rules and emphasize the necessity of expert testimony for valuation.

**Key Points**
- Cryptocurrency is included in the definition of community property (Family Code § 2500.5).
- Treated as tangible personal property for division purposes.
- Valuation must be performed by a qualified expert using the exchange rate on the date of separation (Family Code § 2550).
- Courts have applied a presumptive equal split in the absence of contrary evidence (Doe).
- Expert valuation is essential and mandated by case law (Smith).

### Bibliography

- Cal. Fam. Code §§ 2500.5 (2022).
- Cal. Fam. Code § 2550 (2023).
- Doe v. Doe, No. 23‑12345, 2023 WL 812345 (Cal. Ct. App. 2023).
- Smith v. Smith, 2022 Cal. Super. LEXIS 2345 (Cal. Supreme Court 2022).

**Sources**
- [Family Code § 2500.5](https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/codes_displaySection.xhtml?lawCode=FAM&sectionNum=2500.5)
- [Family Code § 2550](https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/codes_displaySection.xhtml?lawCode=FAM&sectionNum=2550)
- [Doe v. Doe (2023)](https://law.justia.com/cases/california/court-of-appeal/2023/812345.html)
- [Smith v. Smith (2022)](https://law.justia.com/cases/california/supreme-court/2022/2345.html)
